title: What's the difference between undergraduate and graduate? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are definite answers to this question and ‘gray area’ answers. The definite differences tend to be of the more trivial nature - they have different course numbers (running in the 200’s and 300’s instead of the 100’s). They tend to be offered to grad students, rather than undergrads. That sort of thing. In the more ‘gray area’ areas. Graduate classes tend to be more specialized and more advanced. This is gray because there are certainly survey courses offered in graduate school, and specialized electives offered to undergraduates. - but again - the graduate classes tend to be more advanced, they cover more ground - are generally taught at a higher level. Graduate classes also tend to be less based on exams and more on practicals and writing. But there are certainly graduate courses with exams. Heck there are even graduate classes that advanced undergraduates take. I’d say that in my own teaching, the main difference is that undergrad classes tend to be shifted toward conveying information to the class, while graduate classes are more geared toward teaching the students to process that information to think about it, to come up with creative interpretations for it - and creative solutions to problem. I remember a class I took in my first year of graduate school. The professor asked us to write an essay on our solution to a biological problem that he identified for us. We all went to the library with the intention of looking up information on this problem and quickly discovered that there was absolutely nothing known about a solution to this problem. The thing I remember most about what came next, is that some of my fellow students were flummoxed, and had no idea on how to proceed. We eventually figured it out. The professor wanted to to synthesize what we knew in general - figure out what could be applied to that problem - and speculate about potential solutions. You would rarely get something like that in an undergrad class - and it was a seminal moment for me - I learned something about freeing one’s mind from the shackles of the known when faced with a problem in the unknown.

Generally, the amount and depth of content. For example, here at Stony Brook there is MAT 313, Abstract Algbera. It covers basic properties of groups - up to and including fundamental theorem of finite abelian groups - and basic ring and field theory - stopped after going a bit into finite fields, do not remember if we learned Eisenstein’s criterion, but my friends taking it this semester have (I took it last year with a different professor). Starting next semester there will also be Abstract Algebra II, which covers modules over rings, more field theory (including some Galois theory), though it is new so I cannot say much. The graduate Algbera I, a one semester course, covers all this in addition to free and Sylow groups and more of the linear algebra parts. Much of the material is seen for the second time, so the problems tend to be more difficult (I doubt you will see the snake lemma on any undergrad midterms) and lead to a better understanding. The graduate courses also tend to cover material that is way beyond the scope of a typical undergrad student - there is just too much mathematical knowledge and maturity needed and not enough time for someone so young to reach that level. However, taking (or auditing) graduate courses as an undergrad is refreshing. It cannot hurt to learn more when you have exhausted the undergraduate department by the end of sophomore year. The curiosity is never appeased. Additionally, Stony Brook has an independent reading course for undergrads if one wishes to examine the same material at a slower pace (e.g. algebraic geometry/topology) and with guidance, but it is much more work than a regular class. Lots of fun though.

A lot of the other answers have covered many of the standard differences already so I won’t rehash them. I will say, that while it’s not universal for either group, one of the biggest differences I saw between teaching and taking biology classes at UC Berkeley, Columbia, and Cambridge for both undergrads and grad students was undergraduates go to class because they have to, graduate students go to class because they want to. Obviously this is a gross generalization and there are certainly plenty of counter-examples for both groups. But in general, most undergrads were plodding through required coursework, just trying to learn what they needed to know to do well in the class and get on to the next thing. It’s not their fault; in the US system they’re often, even in their third and fourth years, taking four or five classes in a single semester, while balancing other requirements like jobs, volunteering, and other distractions. The UK tutorial system is different and maybe does a better job of getting students more fully engrossed in the subject matter because it’s more focused on narrower topics at greater depth. Grad students, by contrast, usually only have a handful of required classes so they can pick ones that really interest them instead of just ones they think they have to take. They don’t take as many classes at the same time as undergrads, and what they’re learning is often being put to use immediately in their research. And for many students nowadays, an undergrad degree is viewed as essential, while a grad degree is a bonus, and the feeling that they’re there because they want to be there is more palpable. So they’re more personally invested in getting the most out of them. The difference in knowledge between undergrads and their instructors is vast, while the difference is much smaller between grad students and theirs. So classes can often be more of a discussion rather than a strictly didactic student / teacher dynamic. All of these factors contributed to my diffferent experiences between the two class types, as both student and instructor.

Hello At your high school you get basic knowledge on different subjects. After high school the straight away programme is bachelor degree at college/university is called as undergraduate course. It is 4 years programme helps to enter into graduate programmes i.e., masters degrees at universities. Instead of 4 years degree you can also choose diploma courses to get into graduate schools.  In other words, the first studies after high school undertaken at university is undergraduate study where you get the knowledge in a specific discipline. Whereas, the graduate studies require the higher level of understanding, greater independence and a specialised knowledge than undergraduate. You become master in a specific subject in graduate program. Undergraduate programs lead to associate's and bachelor's degrees and that graduate programs lead to master's and doctoral degrees. If you want to go for higher education in states then as an international student, you have to find the top undergraduate program or the best graduate program that fits your needs. The major difference you can find between undergraduate & graduate studies are: Time: Studying any degree is depends on one’s requirement, someone may study to get job, someone may study get expert in subject. In undergraduate school, you can select four years programme OR short term diploma programmes equivalent to undergraduates. Diploma courses need two or less years to complete. Graduate programmes mostly two years or one year programmes which help one who wants to become master in a specific subject. Fees & Scholarships: For four years undergraduate programmes you need to pay high fee than a graduate programme. It is varies from university to university and schools to schools. You get funds for graduate programmes from third party organisations OR universities you choose. Learning & Knowledge Enhancement: As I mentioned above you will learn more about the subjects which already have a course curriculum been set. Master’s programmes help you to get excel knowledge in the subjects theoretically and practically. Explore your professional Network: It is other big difference. You can’t get more professional network in your school & undergraduate but master’s at university is the best platform to explore the professional network and gain more knowledge and opportunities.

Undergraduate degrees offer more of a breadth with some depth. The breadth of the degree is essentially foundational education, while the depth is the actual courses in your major. You have to earn an undergraduate degree before you can be eligible for pursuing a graduate degree. A graduate degree is more focused on a specific area. There are no foundational courses to take like you did in undergrad. That said, graduate school normally has admission standards in terms of GPA and GRE or GMAT scores. You will do a more intense study of your subject at this level. Be prepared to read a lot and be prepared to write some papers. Your expected proficiency in writing is a lot higher at the graduate level. I have been known to tell some students that they needed to run take a writing course fast if they wanted to stay in graduate school. Otherwise, they weren't going to last but for perhaps another semester. Testing varies depending upon the programs. My graduate experience included one essay test at the end of the semester - better get it right or you're screwed. Normally, no more than two C's are allowed for the program. You are asked to leave on your third "C" in most schools. There is normally a set of comprehensives at the end of the program which is essentially a final exam on every course you had in the program. However, not all do that. Sometimes y ou are also given an oral exam by an examining committee in addition to your written exams. Finally, some programs require you to write a thesis, which demonstrates your ability to do research - normally some type of duplication study. You normally have a thesis defense in front of your examining committee as well. While more is expected at the graduate level, there is also more latitude in how you get there. Grad study is challenging, but I found it to be more enjoyable.

Undergrad years are those preceding your receipt of a BA or BSc. Grad school happens while you’re pursuing a post-baccalaureate degree, like an MSc, MA, MD, MFA, LLB, PhD, MEng, and so forth. Grad school is much more focussed than is the undergrad IN THE US AND CANADA. In North America undergrad years comprise not only courses in one’s major but also courses to satisfy breadth requirements which is why, for example, English majors or required to take Physics and Physics majors are required to take Art History and at some schools one must take a minor in addition to a major. That constitutes a huge difference between grad and undergrad: Law students take law courses in the law school; PhD students in Chemistry take courses in their own department, MArch students take courses in architecture, and so forth. Now all of this changes outside of the US and Canada- in most of the world (AFAIK and I’m not familiar with every system so forgive me if I overstate this), one only or predominantly takes courses in their own discipline even at the undergrad. In those settings I’m not as sure what the differences are.

The class sizes are much smaller and the discussion is much more intimate. Instead of five or six classes you take only two or three. For all of my graduate coursework, there is much more reading, evaluation, and presentations. On top of that, you are expected to also work on a long-term project, such as a thesis or a portfolio, as well as attend and present at conferences and network with your colleagues. The classes are much more focused within your discipline as well. I realize some people are saying graduate school is a choice; it might be for some, but for many it is hardly a choice. A graduate degree is the new Bachelor’s degree for many professional fields in advancing your career. That being said, graduate school is not something to jump into. The academic world isn’t for everyone, and there are always different paths to take.

It depends on the discipline.  In the humanities, you choose a topic that interests you, read all of the important stuff that has been written about it, and write a thesis.  It's largely self-directed, and incredibly rewarding if you have chosen your topic wisely.  You should end up understanding your topic as well as anyone in the world does, and more importantly, you should have mastered the basics of your discipline. If you are ambitious, you may also master an interdisciplinary context. One of my students used her dissertation on the poet Coleridge as an excuse to read the neo-platonists, something she'd been wanting to do in any case; another read lots of Spinoza. Unfortunately, there is a lot of pressure these days on academics to ensure that their students submit and pass their dissertations, which in turn leads to pressure on the students to choose narrow topics which can be finished within a short period of time.  While that increases the pass rate, it may also shortchange  students who lose the great opportunity presented by an old-fashioned dissertation--to read widely, and to 'complete' their education. If you are ambitious, you should to some extent ignore your supervisor's attempts to make you narrow your topic at least until you have done the wider reading you want to.  But be aware that writing a proper dissertation will take you a year or two longer than a pro forma effort, and that the costs (in lost income and in day to day expenses) will be greater. Given that there are no jobs in academia for humanities graduates, and that you can expect the cost of housing to double during the years you will spend writing a PhD, don't even think of writing one if there are any remunerative alternatives which appeal to you. Stick to a master's thesis unless you are really, really committed.

Their level of education is obviously one thing.It depends what field they work in, as to differences of how they work.As a graduate student, the thing I noticed the most was the amount of work teachers expect a graduate student to do. I wanted to say, “"Are you kidding me?” Example, expect a history major in graduate school to read 50 pages for homework in one class and write a research paper due the next day. Bummer! The next day? another one!One of my assignments as a music major was to research ALL the musicians that were pianists. It took me all semester to do this assignment while I was also assigned multiple research papers and projects.So the work is mostly research, writing, and making class presentations. Sometimes you give presentations.Another thing, I think graduate students are treated with more respect by their professors. This is great! They find out you are human and don’t talk down to you.Plus, I felt smarter. I guess I thought, if I can do all this massive amount of work, I can do anything. I also got really good at learning and memorizing fast. You have no time to mess around. My grades were also so awesome!

This is a good question. I only knew about this because my undergraduate geography department at the University of Toronto allowed me to take a graduate seminar in Location Theory and the department offered several joint undergrad/graduate courses. Undergraduate courses are more likely to have lectures, multiple assignments and tests/exams. Graduate courses are often seminars, which means you will participate more in each class and will occasionally lead a class, the classes are smaller, and your grade may be based solely on participation and one paper. These are not hard and fast rules. There are undergraduate courses that run like a graduate course and grad courses, usually in statistics, math or operations research, that are straight-forward lecture, assignments and tests.

Here’s an overview of degree levels in the US: Associate’s degree - a two-year degree, typically in an applied field connected with a specific job (AAS) or in preparation for transferring to a four-year school (AS or AA)Bachelor’s degree - a four-year degree, typically what someone means in the US when they say “college degree”; there are many different kinds, but they amount to equivalent levels of educationProfessional degrees - these are graduate degrees and require a bachelor’s degree, but a special subclass, like the JD (juris doctor, the first legal degree)Master’s degrees - these are graduate degrees and require a bachelor’s degree, but exist across many fieldsDoctoral degrees - these are graduate degrees, require a bachelor’s degree (and possibly a master’s degree), and are usually the terminal degree for a field (as in, there are no further academic credentials available)

The overall difference is that undergraduate degrees must be completed prior to a graduate degree may be pursued. Undergraduate degrees tend to be more general, whereas graduate degrees will normally be more specific. This means the average class size in undergraduate degrees will be larger, since graduate degrees are more specialized. Graduate degrees also have the tendency to be more research specific. I work at University of the People and believe that our program pages should make it a bit easier to understand the differences between your route of receiving each degree type. You would be able to view the differences between the Associate’s degree, Bachelor’s degree, and Master’s degree for our Business Administration program to compare the details of each degree program.

Well, obviously graduate courses are more advanced than undergraduate and many rely heavily on what was learned at the undergraduate level. I only took one graduate course in Chemical Engineering. It was taught at night twice a week by the department chairman. My fraternity brother also taking Chem E. and I applied and were granted permission to take the course. We were the only undergraduates. It was no different than the undergraduate with the exception, as previously mentioned, it assumed you had a good underlying knowledge of the undergraduate courses. The course was on Catalyst and I recall one problem my fraternity brother and I worked on as a team of calculating the size of a reactor with and without a catalyst. You knew what the feed stock was and you were told what the product would be and the size of the pipe used as the reactor and the temperature environment. We were given the effects of the catalyst used. The trick was by trial and error to calculate the length of the pipe require in each case. The end result was that with the catalyst the pipe was considerably shorter in length. This didn’t require anything above undergraduate Unit Operations knowledge except it involved the catalyst.

Undergraduate classes emphasize well-defined course materials, projects and homeworks, and include rigorous grading (unless you are at Harvard). Graduate courses often cover newer, narrower topics and encourage students to explore related material they find interesting. Graduate courses often include presentations by students, and average grade in graduate courses is higher.

Both these terminologies can be quite confusing for some people because the same two terminologies have different meanings in other parts of the world. What is considered as an undergraduate degree in the US might mean a graduate degree in some other country. Therefore in the US, an undergraduate program is a 4-year college bachelor's degree program or a 2-year associate's degree program whereas a graduate program is a 1-6-year college master's degree program, for someone who already has a bachelor's degree. Simultaneously there’s a substantial difference in the cost of both the programs. A graduate program can cost you around $30,000+ at public colleges/universities $40,000+ at private colleges/universities and an undergraduate program can cost you $3,000 for associates/2-year degree $9,000+ for 4-year degree, state residents at public colleges/universities $23,000+ for 4-year degree, out-of-state residents at public colleges/universities $31,000+ for 4-year degree, private colleges.

In the universities that I’ve worked for in Australia and Europe, the goal of undergraduate classes is to build up knowledge and understanding for the student on core professional competencies. This is so that when the student graduate from their undergraduate studies, they can be expected to know certain things on their subject area because they have passed the courses. The higher level graduate classes on the other hand, are more in-depth investigations into particular subject areas. They often are used by professors to attract the best and brightest students to their particular area of research.

Typically, the difference lies in the required previous knowledge to be able to understand the class. Just as undergraduate courses have prerequisites so that one can take them in the proper order and make sense of the material presented, so do graduate classes need specific previous knowledge. It's really just a continuous spectrum of  material that needs more background as you progress. Some schools have restrictions on whether undergrads can take grad courses, but usually these can be waived if one has the proper prerequisites and knowledge.

Answer: Undergraduate programs mean that students have completed high schools and are studying for a bachelor degrees, associate degrees or diploma courses. After students have successfully completed their undergraduate bachelor degrees, they are said to be graduates with degrees, and can then proceed if they have good grades to do post-graduate studies in the Australian university system, such as a post-graduate diploma (e.g Dip Ed) or Master's or PhD degrees. Post-graduate students are known as Graduate students doing their master's and PhD in the American university system. Hope this helps. Best wishes.

Roughly speaking, the most important difference is: Undergraduate courses are about things we already know. The focus is on conveying it clearly and crisply. Graduate courses are about things we don’t yet know. The focus is on exploration. Everything else is secondary or irrelevant or wrong.

I’m TAing a computational geometry class this term that has sections for both grad students and undergrads. The background expected is the same, and the lectures are the same, but the homework and exam problems for the grad students are somewhat harder. To be more explicit, we can classify the differences using Bloom’s taxonomy:  Most of the work for undergrads is in the middle two levels, understanding and applying. The work for the grad students includes a much higher proportion of questions from the highest level. In particular, we ask grad students to create algorithms to solve new problems using the ideas learned in class. Often that requires combining multiple different steps from previous problems.

An undergraduate student is someone who has earned a high school diploma or GED certificate and is studying at a college for an associates degree or a bachelors degree. A Graduate student, is someone who has earned a bachelors degree from a college and is continuing to study at a college to earn a masters degree or higher (Engineers degree or PhD or MD, etc.) Typically an undergraduate student is attempting to earn a bachelors degree and a graduate student already has earned a bachelors degree.

undergraduate schools or colleges are for high school graduates to enroll and study leading up to the bachelor degrees which normally take 4 year. after getting the bachelors, then students can go up higher to graduate schools leading up to the masters or PhDs degrees..these are advanced levels in the fields of studies….. there are also called professionals who also go to graduate professional schools like medicine, dentistry, law, architecture. These fields are recruiting interested bachelors to become professionals which are unique specialists .

On average, a student in an undergraduate class has to be there, while the student in the graduate class wants to be there. That difference transforms how the class is received, engaged with, and therefore what is learned, by both the professor and the students.

Undergraduate is a pre-graduate program. This means that you are studying at university to obtain your bachelor's degree. These can be bachelors in science (BSc) for example or many others. They usually last for about 3 years when you’re approximately around age 18 - 20. Once you obtain your bachelor’s, you have graduated from university and so are considered a graduate. A graduate program is, therefore, the next step in academia and you typically work towards a master’s degree. As an example, the masters in science (MSc) can last 9 months or a year depending on the university. Hope it clarified.

Are you asking about the difference between undergraduate and graduate person or the courses or the admissions in undergraduate and graduate courses ?Please write the question clearly. Assuming that you are asking about the difference between the undergraduate and graduate courses. Here is the answer :Undergraduate courses are less specialized but they do take you into one definite career direction in general. Graduate courses are highly specialized which take you into a very specific field of study. RegardsAnimesh

For me, the difference was my assumption that at the graduate level, I believed that (most) students had functional mastery of basic concepts and vocabulary in the field. Thus I could concentrate on exploring interesting advanced concepts in the field. At the undergraduate level, my assumption on walking into the classroom was that students understood basically nothing in the field. So my job there was to bridge the gulf between (a) what bright folks had learned in their daily lives and (b) the professional ideas and concepts I wanted them to master by the end of the course.

Undergraduate refers to someone who is going for their Bachelor's Degree or one who doesn't have an equivalence to a Bachelor's Degree. (Ex. non-degree holder or an Associates Degree would be considered undergraduates)  Graduate refers to someone who is going for a degree that is beyond a Bachelor's Degree. (Ex. Master's Degree or PhD)

Honestly, for most graduate programs (unless they demand an undergrad degree prior to admission), they start you off toward the bottom & build you up from there. The difference is the pace & expectation. Things move faster & you’re expected to learn & understand more deeply at that rate. I’ve had classes where the homework & quizzes were hard & tricky, but the exams were relatively easy & the professor gave ample prep. I’ve also had classes where everything was difficult & the only prep they offered was to remind you a week prior of the upcoming exam. More is expected through projects—team building, thinking outside the box, using outside resources—homework questions, and exams. They expect you to use the information they provide to build onto your knowledge & then apply it all in developing something knew. It isn’t simply regurgitating & memorization.

Graduate program is more research oriented. It focuses on the particular field that you studying. Graduate program generally requires thesis. Undergraduate program starts out broader and more general courses. As you progress, Junior and Senior courses will focuses more on your major and will have assignments and projects. Undergraduate rarely require thesis. What are the differences between Undergraduate and Graduate programs?

Undergraduate students take undergraduate classes and graduate students take graduate classes, that's essentially the difference. The material in a graduate class is presented in greater detail and with higher standards expected from the students. Otherwise, they're pretty much the same. You have lectures or discussions and tests or papers.

Graduate can be anyone who completed their bachelor's degree and may be pursuing his/her masters degree… You can call yourself as undergraduate (as the name suggests) if you are yet to complete your bachelor's. I'll give you one example if a person is participating in a competition you call him contestant but, you call him winner only when he is able to win the race :P Here, contestant = undergraduate Winner = graduate. Hope that's helpful. :)

Undergraduate A student who is pursuing his/her Bachelor degree (Or any after 12th) from a university happens to be a Undergraduate student. Graduate A student who is successfully completed his/her degree from a university is a graduate student. Thanks for A2A....!!

As Brandon has mentioned, it's all about the depth of study. In undergrad, we learned economics, and only disseminated into microeconomics and macroeconomics. We mostly studied the various theories and touched lightly on how they primarily influence our business environment. In grad school however, we went into the ripple effects of these theories and what the assumptions mean for the economy. We also develop models based on these theories identified their strengths and weaknesses, and went deeper into the various inclusions that need to be made to support them, as well as all factors that need to be considered before pursuing/implementing a certain chain of thought. Here, it also stops being about the answers, and becomes more about the practicality of your approach. If you can that your approach is applicable, then what you have is the correct answer.

An undergraduate student is a person enrolled in a bachelor's degree. He/she starts right after high school. In Europe, thanks to the Bologna's process, he/she will study for 3 years. A graduate student is a person already owning a title who is keeping studying in order to specialise him/herself with a master's degree. In Europe it depends: sometimes they endure 2 years, sometimes 1. Most of the time, a master is an annual course.

aside from general difficulty and knowledgebase required, grad classes are (1) often a lot narrower in focus and (2) often cover new knowledge that has recently emerged from research, or is actively being researched and thus is on its way to (potentially) becoming canonized.

A2A. Specializations are the difference between graduate and undergraduate. Usually undergraduate has upper division courses that are introductory, and graduate has the upper division, graduate, and seminar courses for each specialization. The seminars discussion the current research.

A graduate degree is supposed to pay more, because supposively the holder is more prepared; although it can also work against you in some economies, like when the expected value is only that of a high-school diploma requirement to work. You also have to look into what that graduate degree is on. If it’s in library keeping and book indexing systems although highly valuable you can’t expect to make that much money, if money is what you’re looking for. Overall more education is better than less, but this is not always the case. Cheap universities or universities from third world countries don’t usually produce good grad students let alone professionals. This for a number of reasons beyond the scope of this question.

Undergraduate courses are classes you take BEFORE you graduate from your four year institution. Graduate courses are classes you take AFTER you graduate from your four year school. Graduate courses are usually taken on your way to a Master’s Degree or a Doctorate.

Undergraduate courses are those courses that make you a graduate after completing high school. Graduate courses are post graduation specialized courses that can only taken after completing your graduation(i.e. your undergraduate course).

Graduate classes tend to cover deeper material. Instead of just exploring a broad areas, lot of graduate classes focus on learning about a subject well. Also, classes tend to be more challenging because the material is usually harder and the professors have higher standards. Workload also tends to be heavier (more reading, writing...).

Well... simply put, the difference between the undergraduate and graduate students are the years of post secondary education they have accumulated. Undergraduate students are working towards getting their bachelor's degrees (associates degrees count too) and graduate students are working towards getting their master's and/or doctorate (Phds) degrees. I hope that answers your question:)

Hey that's a really nice question you asked. Many people, in India specifically, think that doing undergraduation is graduation but that's not true. In undergrad we mainly decide our major and study a bit more of the subject we have taken in college that's why it's known as bachelor's degree but when we get perfect in our desired subject which we do in Masters degree and getting any master is known as doing graduation but getting any bachelor's degree is known as doing the major or “undergraduation”. This concept is not widely known in India but when we apply to foreign country for studies or for a job we get to know the difference in between them as they consider the PG degree as a grad degree and that's why their MBA college are sometimes known as grad school. I hope I've cleared your all doubts about undergrad and grad degree. If not ask me in comments.

“I know that undergraduate programs lead to associate's and bachelor's degrees and that graduate programs lead to master's and doctoral degrees. What are some of the other differences? Answer: There are, of course, manydifferences.Apr 21, 2015” What are the differences between Undergraduate and Graduate ... https://www.studyusa.com/.../what-are-the-differences-between-underg...

an undergraduate is a student who has not yet completed all of their school's requirements for their degree, and have not received their degree. a graduate has. a graduate student is a student continuing who is continuing their studies for a master's, then doctorate degree.

I’ll give an example. This is a question on quora regarding probability: The probability that a boy will pass in examination in 3/5 and that for a girl is 2/5then what is probability that atleast one of them passes in examination? You can see the answer feed and realise that they all make the implicit assumption that there are 2 pupils in the class. Well, that’s undergrad education. Graduate education is about framing first the right question before trying to answer it.

Being a graduate means you have completed your bachelor's degree. Undergraduate means you are yet to complete your bachelor's degree. You can simply understand as Undergraduate= UNDERCONSTRUCTION Graduation = Constructed Undergraduates are on their road to graduation. Pully (my nickname)

Undergraduate class count toward an undergraduate degree and are often prerequisites, along with the undergraduate degree of course, for graduate school classes and programs. Graduate school classes count toward a masters degree or Ph.D. or some other advanced degree. There can be some overlap in how the classes apply toward degrees. It depends on the university.
And undergraduate is in his/her first four years of college. A graduate student is working on an advanced degree (MA / PhD) after receiving his / her baccalaureate degree.

A person can do under graduation courses after passing 12th standard. It includes many courses the popular ones are BCOM BTECH BBA BCA BSC and many more. After passing one of these courses a person can be called under graduated. Under Graduation is necessary to applying for jobs. Today graduation is the minimum requirement for a normal official job in public or private sector. A person can do graduation after under graduation . It includes some popular courses like MTECH,MCOM,MBA,MCA,MSC etc.

Undergrad is Bachelors degree and is right after you complete high school Graduate refers to the course after undergrad which is basically known in some countries as Masters or Post-graduation program.

An undergraduate education is usually broad. It consists of courses that make one a more educated person generally [liberal arts and sciences], as well as some in a specific discipline. A Masters degree is usually very narrowly specific and related to a particular discipline or career field [Example, a MA in photography or cinema]. A Doctorate is broad but focused around a general area [Example: a Doctorate in Media Studies, Literature or Art History].
Undergrad is the first four years of college working towards a bachelors degree. Graduate programs are 1–6 years leading to a masters or PhD. What else are you asking?
What? Undergrad is perhaps an u undeclared major. Where are you going?
Undergrad describes the course work that you will take to get you bachelors degree whereas graduate describes the work you will take to get a masters or phd

A person learn subjects related to his in graduation. Undergraduate he's / she's are fresh for all these subjects. After graduating they are expertise, increase efficiency, ready for executing all things they learned in graduation.
Undergraduate is some one who is pursing graduation level studies and graduate is someone who has pursued the graduation level of education
All bachelor’s degree courses fall in undergraduate courses; and all master’s degree courses fall under graduate courses.

Under-graduation is what you study to become a graduate. Graduation is what you study after you have become a graduate. This is the conventional way you refer to in overseas universities. What they call graduation is actually what we call in India as post graduation.
An undergraduate is one who is yet to complete his/her university/College departmental courses requirements, while a graduate is one who does.

A degree course is often taken after completing +2 , here in Tamil nadu,the courses being offered In Medical Engineering Commmerce Nursing. Etc., On the other hand, a diploma course is a 3 year  Course in after 10th. They are offered in various branches of engineering and in other fields also. It is a shorter duration course for employment to supervisory level Whereas your degree level education takes you to an executive or officer level post.
Just more detailed, difficult, specialized learning, with (usually) a better grade of student, and often more direct contact with the professors.
PG has cocksucker with titleUG has only cunt with degree until 35 years older older then beforeolder then before;than; cunt
